item.title: Ann Arbor City Council Preview for 17 August 2015
item.description:
Ann Arbor City Council meets at 7:00 p.m. on Monday, 17 August 2015. A preview of the agenda is on Arborwiki, complete with a map, on the tag 2015-08-17CCMTG.

Some highlights to note:

The consent agenda includes $36,412 for the purchase of 21 Taser weapons. This is a sole-source purchase, to replace weapons purchased in 2003.

Also on the consent agenda is $83,000 for a sole-source purchase to renew the CityWorks license, which is used for asset tracking and maintenance of city owned resources. Of that amount, $20,000 will be billed back to the Washtenaw County Water Resources Commissioner.

$110,000 would go for the continuation of CLEMIS Public Safety Information Sharing Services for the Ann Arbor Police Department for FY2016. CLEMIS runs the dispatch system for police and allows “information sharing” with other departments. It’s run by Oakland County.

HathiTrust has digitized many decades of Ann Arbor City Council minutes, and it it proposed that the city approve publication of those minutes through HathiTrust by clearing the copyright on those materials.

Public hearings include one on deer management, and there’s a proposal on the agenda to spend $90,000 on some combination of a deer cull by sharpshooters and sterlization of deer. Expect this to be a long public hearing.

In development news, there’s a proposed condominium development on N Main St adjacent to North Main Park, and hearings on proposed annexations on Nixon Road and on Ann Arbor - Saline Road.

If you’re following the footing drain disconnect program closely, you’ll note that there’s a proposal to lend the builder of 618 South Main footing drain disconnect credits to allow for full occupancy of that building.

More of course at the full agenda. See you on the site plan barricades (er, see you at council).

item.title: I voted, summer 2015 edition
item.description:
Ann Arbor is one of three peculiar communities in the state of Michigan to have partisan City Council elections; the other two are Ypsilanti and Ionia. This has in recent years meant that the races that decide the makeup of City Council happen in the summer when students are gone and when voter turnout is very low.

I did vote, and I do plan to go to at least one of the parties celebrating victory or acknowledging defeat by the candidates who have the remaining funds from their campaign to put out a nice spread for supporters, hangers-on, or the perpetually politically curious.

After a few rounds of picking up result tapes from Ward Four precincts, I ended up at Arbor Brewing Company which was Council Party HQ.

Winners:

  • First Ward: Sabra Briere over Will Leaf, handily with 70%+ of the vote, though only 6% of registered voters actually voted.
  • Second Ward: We’ll wait until the fall for this as Jane Lumm (I) meets Sally Hart Petersen (D) in November.
  • Third Ward: Zachary Ackerman defeats Steve Kunselman by about 40 votes. This was the surprise of the night. Ackerman’s entire margin of victory was his strong showing in 3-3 (Burns Park) where he outpaced Kunselman 345-171. Turnout was under 11%.
  • Fourth Ward: Jack Eaton defeats Jamie Magiera with about 60% of the vote. Jack held his party at Wolverine Brewing; Jamie was at ABC, looking subdued. Turnout was about 10%.
  • Fifth Ward: Chip Smith defeated Mike Anglin with about 55% of the vote. Voter turnout in the mighty Fifth Ward was strong compared to the other wards, with a mighty 14% of the electorate turning out to vote.

Losers:

  • The 85%+ of Ann Arbor voters who didn’t know enough or didn’t bother to turn out to vote.

Details:

  • UnOfficial Election Results, August 4, 2015 City Primary Election, Wasthenaw County

item.title: Michigan Emergency Incidents and overnight storm report
item.description:
Michigan Emergency Incidents is a news service that covers emergency dispatch around the state of Michigan. Members of a closed Facebook group post call-outs of emergency services operations, and there’s generally follow up from other members to note incidents in progress or news stories written from the scene.

All information contained in MEI posts is to come from received radio transmissions heard directly from radios / scanners or via an online broadcast, verified reliable sources, or first hand knowledge (ie you are on scene).

Follow along on Twitter @MEIDispatch; the twitter feed has the current link to the private Facebook group, which regularly accepts qualified new members.

Storm last night. We got a downpour, some wind and lightning, but nothing too bad. A nearby City of Ann Arbor rain gauge on S Industrial reported 1.12” of rain, and at the peak of the storm rain was coming down at 0.41” in 15 minutes. The scanner was full of power lines sparking and trees down.

Worst hit was the Sleeping Bear Dunes area, where some of the adjacent communities had complete power blackouts. There was also a tornado in the Thumb. The National Weather Service recap for the August 2, 2015 storms gives much more detail. Softball sized hail was seen near West Branch, MI.

Current 8:45 a.m. report is 60,318 DTE Energy customers without power, and 91,802 Consumers Energy customers without power. DTE does not generally report outages by county, just by zip code, but I have all of the zip codes so I should be able to estimate county level totals.

item.title: a2b3 lunch non-summary at Blue Nile for 30 July 2015
item.description:
Nice lunch today at the Blue Nile. We had 10 people for lunch, including two people (Azita Azadi and Tom Meloche) who had moved back to town from far away. I had the vegetarian plate which was delicious (love me some injera).

The question of the day was regarding postcards, something I’m thinking about quite a bit. With a modest (but still too big) amount of effort I can launch a postcard from the command line of my Mac. It’s got to be easier (so I don’t have to look up command line options) but the basic structure works pretty well.

Postcards are archaic, perhaps, and also perhaps more expensive per each than reaching someone through Facebook advertising. I do have to say though that I love sending them, and love receiving them in return. I’d love to do the experiment of $20 spent on Facebook vs $20 spent on postcards, and wonder what the return would be; or better yet, $20 spent on each and identify particular synergies between super-high-tech and old-fashioned.

The card I got in the mail today was from Peter Honeyman and Lynn Chamberlain, two of my faithful correspondents. They sent a photo of the Pickle Barrel House Museum in Grand Marais, Michigan. The historic marker there reads:

The Pioneer Cooperage Company of Chicago designed this small vacation cottage, which stood on the shores of nearby Sable Lake from 1926 until about 1937. It was built for William Donahey, creator of the Chicago Tribune cartoon story The Teenie Weenies. The house was constructed as a typical barrel would have been, only on a much larger scale. The main barrel contained a living area on the first floor and a bedroom on the second. A pantry connected this barrel to a smaller single-story one, which housed a kitchen. Donahey spent ten summers at the cottage with his wife, Mary, herself a noted author of children’s books. The structure was then moved to its current site and used as a tourist information center. The Pickle Barrel House is listed in the National Register of Historic Places.

Sounds like a destination for next time!

item.title: restaurant inspections
item.description:
Every month the Washtenaw County Health Department does a round of restaurant inspections. Wayne Eaker built an importer that pulls in data from the site that hosts the official county inspections, and is storing the inspection data on Github to make it easier for the next person who wants to build a nice interface to all the data.

Wayne was good enough to find a spot to host an interface to this data that lets you browse through it; you can find it at

http://food-inspections.annarbortelegraph.com

There are permalinks to each inspection so that you can link to them. See e.g. recent inspections for

  • Slurping Turtle, June 17, 2015
  • China Chef, Ypsilanti, April 27, 2015
  • Nu Wave Fish and Chicken, June 22, 2015

for three examples of places where I want to see a clean inspection on a followup visit before I go or go back to there.

item.title: Daily coffee and wifi at Argus Farm Stop
item.description:
Daily coffee and wifi at Argus Farm Stop, outside in the sunshine under a lovely red umbrella canopy. Espresso over ice and a day-old olive twist. The view is of a Sky Trak lift at the construction site across moving materials to the back of The Mark, a building that’s going up where the car wash used to be.

The news of the day is a death on State Street. A young man was climbing over the skylights at the Nickels Arcade and fell to his death when the skylight glass gave way.

On July 24, 1915, the SS Eastland was packed with employees from the Western Electric Hawthorne Works when it rolled over in the Chicago River. 844 passengers and crew lost their lives, making the Eastland disaster the worst shipwreck on the Great Lakes. See the Eastland Disaster Historical Society for extensive notes on and photos of the scene and its aftermath.

The next meeting of a2civictech is coming up on Monday, July 27, 2015.

Literati Bookstore is open again after a water leak caused them to shut down.

A few months ago I wrote a tiny R script that generates maps. The challenge today is to find a portable environment so that I can deploy this script on shared infrastructure. The project took 30 minutes of MacBook Air processor time running full blast parallel, and while I don’t care about wall clock time to complete the effort I do care about building something that I can hand off to someone else to run.

The hope is that the ropensci Docker package from the Rocker project is the answer, or most of the answer, for this. Rocker has built R images where lots of useful packages have been installed, including systems where the install directions are a little bit complex.

With all complicated software environments the biggest challenge is dealing with dependencies. If you want to use the latest and greatest fast algorithms, you have to be prepared to spin up on what the cool kids are doing in the rest of their environment. If somehow you can jump to the edge of the development in the algorithm world without being tripped up by the hairy dependency graph that got you there, it can be a lot more fun.

So; install Docker on the Mac with ‘boot2docker’; then

docker pull rocker/ropensci
docker run -it rocker/ropensci R

and poof, you have an environment current to this month’s desktop of leading R developers.

item.title: Library notes from Malletts Creek
item.description:
Out for a bike ride to Malletts Creek Branch Library after a delicious lunch of BBQ at Ricewood.

One of the challenges of low overhead custom postcard making is getting an image manipulation pipeline that kicks out photos that a appropriately cropped and sized. The latest challenge is identifying the single command line that will turn a photo from my phone’s camera into an appropriately sized image for the card with a minimum of cropping, distortion, and manual file transfers.

What I know doesn’t work is upload via Twitter, because the series of resizings generate visible compression artifacts.

I can upload from the phone to OneDrive, which gives me a photo of size 2592 × 1456 pixels (1.78:1, 16:9). The target size is 1875 x 1275 (1.47:1, 25:17), which is postcard format. I can keep all of the pixels in the image by letterboxing it, or I can crop off the edges. What I can’t really do is stretch the image to fit because it’s too far off.

Looking further at my camera software (Lumia Camera) it appears that I can also take photos at 4:3. There’s more experimenting to be done.

For more documentation, see Efficient Image Resizing With ImageMagick, Dave Newton in Smashing Magazine, June 25, 2015. Dave goes through a professionally thorough view of resizing and resampling images for the web, comparing his results against Photoshop. For instance:

I tested 31 different settings for -filter and got the best results with Triangle. The Triangle resampling filter is also known as bilinear interpolation, which I discussed above. It determines pixel color by looking at a support area of neighboring pixels and produces a weighted average of their colors. I found it best to specify this support area at two pixels using the -define filter:support=2 setting.

Dave uses DSSIM from https://pornel.net/dssim to test his results.

This tool computes (dis)similarity between two PNG images using (my approximation of) algorithms approximating human vision. Comparison is done in L*ab color space using a multi-scale variant of the SSIM algorithm.

There are sites that have automatic crop algorithms, though I haven’t yet found a package that’s usable without licensing. The interactive web site of Croppola is one useful example of this genre.

Pittsburgh’s smallest jazz club is installed in a bus stop on Liberty Avenue, across from 9th Street. The shelter was installed on July 6 and will remain until late August 2015. From the New Pittsburgh Courier Online:

Awesome Pittsburgh’s trustees smiled unanimously when they decided to choose the proposal for one of 2014’s $1000 grants, envisioning a bus patron who pushes a button, only to have an iPod play jazz music from one of MCG Jazz’s Grammy Award winning recordings. The interior walls of a bus shelter will feature images of Pittsburgh’s jazz legends, and a blank “Your Face Here!” space to take a picture of yourself at “Pittsburgh’s Smallest Jazz Club.” Lamar Outdoor, owner of the bus shelters in Pittsburgh and Allegheny County, is already on board to help make the project happen.

The project was done by MCG Jazz - Amy Kline is their marketing manager.

Network issues at Malletts Creek branch were a good reason to exit back towards town.

item.title: Commuter North and South
item.description:
A bus labeled “TRAINING”. Don’t take that one.

Kayakers in bright yellow kayaks on the Huron River under the bridge on Fuller Road.

Would it be too much to ask to have wifi actually on the blue bus, or is it more reasonable to expect that people have cell data coverage everywhere and that wifi on the bus is for long haul buses like Megabus?

I’m happy that with Hugo I can have a reasonably complete local blogging environment completely independent of having Internet access, so long as I have my computer with me. On the other hand doing live-blogging from a phone is not possible, not that it ever really was very practical with any previous setup).

“Your UMARC shack access code is …” Achievement unlocked.

The todo list right now for the shack is very short - “get in”. Now that I’m in I should have a longer list. There is a lot of gear in that room to get familiar with, not least of which is HF equipment with tunable and movable antennas.

Why Twitter Has More Freedom To Innovate Than Google is a 2013 Wired Magazine writeup. Prominently featured are Marius Eriksen, Niels Provos, and Peter Honeyman.

This was in the early aughts, when Eriksen was an undergrad at Michigan, studying computer science under a professor and lovable eccentric named Peter Honeyman. Known as “Dr. Honey” among the undergrads and PhD students at his Center for Information Technology Integration, Honeyman was famous for making assignments without really making assignments. “He would develop a particular obsession, and he would give you random hints about it, but he wouldn’t actually tell you what to do,” Eriksen remembers. “You would end up collaborating with people on whatever it was, in this freeform way, without much direction at all.”

I talked to one of Peter’s current students. Evan is looking at ways to direct RF energy at devices to make them fail in interesting ways.

Stanford, Berkeley, and the University of Michigan are working on the Secure Internet of Things Project (slashdot):

Stanford, Berkeley, and the University of Michigan have now started the Secure Internet of Things Project, which aims to promote security and transparency for IoT devices. They hope to unite regulators, researchers, and manufacturers to ensure nascent internet-connected tech is developed in a way that respects customer privacy and choice.

The web site has more details at http://iot.stanford.edu .

Among the presentations at the Secure Internet of Things Project Retreat in Half Moon Bay on June 5, 2015 was this by U of Michigan’s Prabal Dutta, State of the Field: Hardware and Systems.

(embed deck here, if I can)

The LP0965 Antenna is a Log Periodic PCB directional antenna, at 5-6dBi Gain. The design is from Kent Britain WA5VJB, and a data sheet for the antenna describes its utility for signals from 850 Mhz to 6500 Mhz. See http://wa5vjb.com for more circuit board antennas for use for hobby, wifi, microwave and cellular use.

Traffic jam on Fuller on the return trip, backed up all the way to the river. It took about 15 minutes to get through because of construction on westbound Fuller taking traffic to one lane. It would have been faster to take the Route 1 AAATA bus via Pontiac Trail, even though it would have been a considerable detour, or to walk to Plymouth Road and take the 2 in.

There was a fire at the Michigan League this afternoon. No sign of any issues as I pass by this evening.

The question when taking Commuter South is always where to get off the bus. Today I’ll take it all the way to the end of its route.

item.title: Daily coffee and wifi at Biggby Packard
item.description:
It’s a warm but pleasant mid-summer late Monday morning, and I’m visiting the first cafe inbound on a walk to town. Biggby Packard is where I end up when the inbound bus schedule timing is just so.

Summertime cafes near campus are odd. There’s not really enough here to motivate someone to drive here for coffee, so it draws people from the surrounding neighborhood and from the athletic campus. I’ve been in here before when I was the only patron for more than an hour but this morning there’s a few more people sitting typing.

I first ran into the “pocketmod” planning technique in 2005, and here it is 10 years later and there’s one in my pocket.

A pocketmod is a cleverly folded piece of paper with preprinted templates for things like a mini calendar, todo list, quadrille paper, checklist etc. It’s the smallest instance of a PDA that I have seen yet, requiring nothing more than a blank piece of paper and a pair of scissors to execute. You could even bypass the scissors if you had good paper and a crisp straightedge to do a rip.

Astoundingly, http://www.pocketmod.com/ is still online, in all of its 2005-2007 glory. That system does an 8-up PDF from a set of templates, so that you can print a lovingly detailed mini booklet. My own use has long since devolved into scrap paper plus rip down the center. When it fills up, invert the fold, and you have a brand new organizer.

Now playing, Johnny Cash’s “One Piece at a Time”. “GM wouldn’t miss just one little piece.” Look for the promo photo.

Menu plan: green beans with walnuts and miso sauce, plus a few green beans uncooked on the side for J who likes to eat the raw. A recipe of sorts is at The Kitchn, which refers to a 2005 New York Times Dining article about Yumiko Kano and her brand of Japanese cooking. Just Bento has some reviews of books by Yumiko Kano (aka Yumiko Kanoh or Kanou Kumiko). The Unbearable Lightness of Being Hungry has a 2009 vegetarian ramen recipe from the same author. There’s a profile of Yumiko Kano in Metropolis.

We got some very yummy new potatoes from Farmers Market that I cooked up last night, which were 1000x more wonderful than storebought old potatoes.

Exit Biggby heading north to North Campus to Mujo’s, for some time spent writing. Close all of the windows, save all of the documents, publish locally all of the works in progress. North Campus has the virute of frequent free bus service from Central Campus, and it’s far enough away to completely flush all of the thoughts of what I had been doing so I can work on another project.

item.title: Remembering Hazen Schumacher of Jazz Revisited
item.description:
Hazen Schumacher was a radio broadcaster who hosted the popular “Jazz Revisited” show on NPR and Michigan Radio (WUOM) for 30 years. He died on July 18, 2015.

Arborwiki’s page on Hazen Schumacher has memories of him and his program. The jazz collection that he assembled and all of the master tapes for the show are now at the Jazz Museum Bix Eiben Hamburg, and 24 editions of the program are up online for your listening at http://bixrevisited.com .

“Jazz Revisited has reached millions, giving Hazen a good claim to be America’s premier jazz educator.” (Art Hilgart - IAJRC Journal). Bix Eiben Hamburg presents 24 different shows at regular intervals for free listening. Dive into the wonderful world of classic Jazz. Become part of the great Jazz fan community that already regularly uses our service free of charge.

A tribute to The Jazz Museum Bix Eiben Hamburg and Jazz Revisited from Jazz-Museum Bixeibenhamburg on Vimeo.

In remembrance of The Jazz Museum Bix Eiben Hamburg and a documentary report about the Jazz Revisited Radio Shows!

item.title: food coop notes for July 18, 2015
item.description:
Some notes over a cup of coffee and some cold roast chicken. I need to mix up my menu selections at the coop more so that I can remember what I was writing by what I ate; I usually eat the same thing!

Peter Honeyman and Lynn Chamberlain were here at the coop, doing the NY Times crossword. (Saturday crossword in 36:05, a mid-day triumph.)

At Farmer’s Market: cherries, parsley, kale, potatoes, dill, tomatoes. The potatoes will be boiled and dressed with a dill vinaigrette. (I had to look up the word vinaigrette.) The recipes I found add green beans and boiled eggs to a salad with cold potatoes, using a mustard vinaigrette with added chopped dill. The cherries will probably just be eaten out of hand.

The UP travel discussion included the obligatory discussion of insects, including ticks (“like bedbugs, for the woods”) and horrible sand flies that will swarm you and leave you screaming running from the beach. There’s a good reason that the UP has miles of undeveloped beaches.

You can’t mention bugs in the UP without remembering The Backyard Arthropod Project, “A Field Guide to the North Side of Old Mill Hill, Atlantic Mine, MI”, by Tim Eisele.

I’m still hacking away at generating interesting reports from the stringdist package from Mark van der Loo. Yesterday’s post was R: producing a list of near matches with stringdist and stringdistmatrix and the answers provided helped unearth the melt() function from the reshape2 library, and with that you take a matrix and turn it into an edge list. A little bit of filtering, and you get a report of near matches in a list, enough for me to catch variant spellings of vinagrette to vinaigrette in a “make test” step.

Stack Overflow was fun for this task, I’m going to try it again. The process of describing your problem in enough detail that someone who knows the issue can add the one or two lines of code to make it work is a useful exercise. It’s the opposite of a search engine in many ways - of course I could find melt() once I know its name, but if you don’t know the name you can’t find anything.

The next bit of interestingness has to do with turning the dist data structure returned by stringdist into a variety of useful images. There’s a package that dumps out a “dendogram”, and if I’m careful in formatting the data I think I can coerce R into producing data that can be imported directly into the tools that Valdis Krebs has written for network exploration and visualization. The promise within R is a “distgraph” that does the visualization, but I’m not yet finding the cadre of experts who use that.

The art on the walls is Julie Marron-Parker’s “Sunburst”. She writes

Let the sun shine.

Living in Michigan (160 days of sun per year) I have come to appreciate when the sun is out. This piece brings the energy of the sun into the world, regardless of the weather outside.

Tom Meloche writes about the doorway effect, where going through a doorway wipes out your short term memory to make way for new short term memories. It got me thinking about the memory palace, and how you might construct in your mind a series of portals and doorways to walk through so that you can remember a series of items in such a way that you take advantage of the doorway effect to pull memories in and out of your short term thinking. The technology is “mnemotechnics”, that’s a good keyword to pull lots of interesting thinking (which sometimes sounds like crazytalk).

That reminds me - I need to move to another room, so that I can remember what I need to do here.

item.title: a2b3 lunch at Ayse's, Art Fair 2015 edition
item.description:
Eight of us met for lunch at Ayse’s today. It was a normal Thursday in that regard, as that’s a pretty typical size for the lunch group these days.

We talked at question time about how we get big chunks of time to work on projects. One answer was to work early in the morning or late at night when there were fewer distractions. Gyll, a remodeling contractor, mentioned the use of checklists to make sure that the things that needed to get done got done. Among the tasks that took up lots more time than they deserved included dealing with the health insurance marketplace and with other healthcare providers for dealing with billing and accounting problems.

Three of the people at lunch were new to the table, but since Ann Arbor is bascially a small town, it was not a surprise to me that I had easily identifiable mutual friends with two of them.

Food was delicious, well prepared and well presented.

Next week we’ll be back at Madras Masala, as art fair will have ended and town will be more back to normal.

The big event coming up is Maker Faire Detroit, to be held at The Henry Ford in Dearborn.

item.title: lunch with jonathan
item.description:
Jonathan and I went to Paradise, a Vietnamese place in the Colonade that also serves Chinese food. He got Mongolian Beef, and I got pho deluxe. It was perfectly adequate if not spectacular. The topic of conversation was an elaborate storyline in a game that involved animatronics in a creepy Chuck E. Cheese type abandoned pizza parlor.

We then went to the Malletts Creek library, until about 4:00 p.m. I worked on Hugo and constructed a theme from scratch. At the end he got bored.

item.title: Arborbike, a first review
item.description:
Plus: fun to ride, big front basket. It's a very nice bike that you're riding, with a good 3 speed shifter and a very sturdy construction.

Minus: no lights, no bell, no helmets. More specifically, I am told that the lights come on automatically, and that there is a bell somewhere, but I didn't find it and it wasn't labeled. I did have a helmet with me so I wore that.

See arborbike.org for more details.
